caption.title: Clock and Wavefront Model for Vertegrate Segmentatioin, Related to Figure 1.
caption.p: This model proposes that the production of somites during embryogenesis results from a molecular oscillator (called the clock) traveling along the embryonic axis. Segment formation is triggered during a defined (permissive) phase of the oscillation, while the oscillator is constantly displaced posteriorly by a maturation wave (the wavefront), hence ensuring the spacing of the response to the oscillator.

caption.title: Imaging Clock Oscillations in teh Mouse Embryo, Related to Figure 1.
caption.p: The periodic, anterior-traveling waves of cyclic gene expression can be seen in the presomitic mesoderm (PSM) of a transgenic mouse embryo. The transgene expresses a destabilized yellow fluorescent protein (YFP) from the cyclic promoter of the Lunatic Fringe (Lfng) gene, an oscillating component of the mouse segmentation clock. See Aulehla et al., 2008 for additional details.
